title: Mazda MX-30: New electric SUV revealed at Tokyo more show
text:
Mazda is charging on to the EV scene with a quirky crossover that blends sports car-inspired aesthetics with SUV practicality and eco-friendly materials.

Whereas most modern SUVs are formulaic in their basic layout — four doors and a boot in a high-riding body — the Mazda MX-30 takes a more radical approach.

The MX-30 takes inspiration from the MX-5 and RX-8 sports cars with a heavily raked roof and rear-hinged back doors.

While it shares its basic architecture with regular petrol-powered Mazdas — opening the possibility of a petrol or hybrid alternative in future — the MX-30 is the first all-electric Mazda and signals the Japanese maker’s intention of riding the EV wave that is generating big interest but slow sales.

Due on sale in Europe in 2020, the MX-30 is on the hit list for Mazda Australia.

“We’re looking at ways of launching that in Australia if there is some demand,” says Mazda Australia managing director Vinesh Bhindi, adding that the lack of charging infrastructure was concerning. “There is a slow change in attitude towards electric and alternative propulsion.”

Program manager Tomiko Takeuchi said the MX-5 two-seat sports car provided inspiration for one of the most radical SUVs on the market.

“We wanted to make the MX-30 a familiar presence and make spending time with the car richer, more fun, and more human.”

As well as the sporty silhouette, the MX-30 showcases modern materials targeted at younger buyers.

Rather than leather, the MX-30 uses cork and recycled plastic bottles.

While Mazda has a technical co-operation with Toyota for hybrid systems, the MX-30’s electrical architecture is wholly Mazda and is claimed to bring innovations.

With a single front-mounted motor powering either the front or all four wheels, the MX-30 has a 35.5kWh battery pack in the floor for around 200km of range.

There is a system called Motor Pedal, which adjusts its response to throttle inputs — and how quickly it accelerates — depending on how fast the driver presses the pedal.

Mazda has also engineered artificial sound pumped through the speakers to better provide real-time feedback as to how hard the electric motor is working.
description: Mazda is charging on to the EV scene with a quirky crossover that blends sports car-inspired aesthetics with SUV practicality and eco-friendly materials.
